questiontext.text: What is automation in the IT context?

answer.text: Using technologies to perform tasks with minimal human intervention to replace human labor
The process of creating robots for physical work

questiontext.text: Which of the following languages are usually NOT used as scripting languages for automation?
When does the need for automation arise?

answer.text: When a sequence of actions requiring accuracy and/or being routine is performed periodically
Only when working with large volumes of data
Only when there are more than 10 developers in a team

questiontext.text: Which of the following factors are NOT advantages of automation?
Which tool is a workflow automation platform built into GitHub?
Which of the following is an automation tool?
What are environment variables?

answer.text: Dynamic values that can affect the behavior of processes in the operating system

questiontext.text: Which environment variable defines the list of directories to search for executable files?
Which symbol is used in Bash to denote the beginning of a shebang?
What will happen when executing the command name = "John" with spaces around the equals sign in Bash?

answer.text: The value will be assigned with spaces

questiontext.text: Which syntax is used to get the length of a string in Bash?
How to perform arithmetic operations with integers in Bash?
Which tool is used for operations with floating-point numbers in Bash?
What is the difference between single and double quotes when working with strings?

answer.text: Variables are not interpolated in single quotes, but are interpolated in double quotes
Single quotes are used for numbers, double quotes for strings
There is no difference, you can use any

questiontext.text: Which syntax is used to extract a substring in Bash?
How to get all elements of an array in Bash?
Which comparison operator is used to check numerical equality in Bash?
Which operator checks that a file exists and is a regular file in Bash?
What does the && operator mean on the command line?

answer.text: Executes the second command only if the first one completed successfully
Executes the second command only if the first one failed

questiontext.text: Which construct is used to check multiple conditions in if statements in Bash?
How to create a numeric range in a for loop in Bash?
What is the difference between while and until loops in Bash?

answer.text: while executes while the condition is true, until - while the condition is false
while is for numbers, until is for strings
There is no difference, they are synonyms

questiontext.text: How to declare a local variable inside a function in Bash?
Which variable contains the number of arguments passed to the Bash script?
What does the set -e command do in Bash?

answer.text: Terminates script execution on the first error

questiontext.text: Which symbol is used to execute a command in the background?
What does the || operator mean on the command line?

answer.text: Executes the second command only if the first one completed successfully
Executes the second command only if the first one failed

questiontext.text: Which comparison operator is used to check if one number is less than another in Bash?
What main software development processes can be automated?

answer.text: Workplace setup, build, deployment and testing
Task complexity assessment, testing and monitoring
Version control, documentation and code review

questiontext.text: What is Web API in the context of automation?

answer.text: A mechanism for integrating disparate services into a unified ecosystem

questiontext.text: What does each field mean in the crontab format * * * * * command?

answer.text: minute hour day_of_month month day_of_week command
second minute hour day month command
hour minute day month year command
minute hour month day_of_month day_of_week command

questiontext.text: Which command is used to edit the current user's crontab?
What does the crontab entry 0 2 * * * /home/user/backup.sh mean?
What data is recommended to include in logs to simplify analysis?

answer.text: Timestamp, severity level, message, process identifier, metadata
Error message, user login, password (if applicable)
Severity level, hostname, code analyzer result

questiontext.text: What approaches are used for effective error handling in automation?

answer.text: Error logging, notifications, retry attempts, fallbacks
Error logging, user interaction, retry attempts

questiontext.text: When should Python be used instead of Bash for automation?

answer.text: When working with complex data structures (JSON, XML), network requests, exception handling
For web development, testing and monitoring

questiontext.text: Which Python module is used for copying files?
What to do if a UnicodeDecodeError occurs when reading a file in a Python script?

answer.text: Try a different encoding or handle the exception
Skip the error line, it's not critical
The file will be deleted, so create a backup copy
Do nothing, the error is ignored

questiontext.text: What is the crontab -l command used for?
What advantages does Web API integration provide in CI/CD?

answer.text: Linking GitHub, GitLab, Jenkins; integration with code analysis tools; project management synchronization
Development acceleration, but only for web applications
Version control; experience sharing; code recommendations

questiontext.text: Where does the cron scheduler look for crontab files?
Which Python module is best suited for logging configuration?
What does os.makedirs(path, exist_ok=True) mean in Python?

answer.text: Creates directory with all parent folders, ignoring if it already exists
Creates directory and raises an error if it exists

questiontext.text: Which tools can be used for automatic log analysis?
What does the parameter sum(1 for _ in f) mean in Python when counting file lines?

answer.text: Efficiently counts lines without loading the entire file into memory
Creates a copy of the file

questiontext.text: What role do cloud platforms play in team development?

answer.text: Collaboration tools, version control, CI/CD pipelines
File storage, task writing, meeting planning
Website hosting, code review, project management, customer interaction

What is Git?
Which command is used to initialize a new Git repository?
What does the git add command do?

answer.text: Creates a new file in the repository

questiontext.text: Which command is used to create a commit in Git?
What information must be configured during initial Git setup?
What is the modern recommended command for switching between branches (Git 2.23+)?
What happens when executing the git clone command?

answer.text: Creates a complete local copy of the remote repository
Creates a link to the remote repository
Copies only the latest changes of a source code
Creates a new feature branch in the current repository

questiontext.text: Which file is used to exclude files from Git tracking?
What does SHA-1 hash mean in Git context?
Which command shows the current state of the working directory?
What is a merge conflict?

answer.text: Git cannot automatically merge changes from different branches
Error when connecting to remote repository
Git version mismatch on different computers
One developer disagrees with another's changes

questiontext.text: Which command is used to view commit history?
Command for undoing changes in the working directory?
What does the git fetch command do?

answer.text: Gets updates from remote repository without automatic merging

questiontext.text: What is the difference between git pull and git fetch?

answer.text: pull gets changes and automatically merges them, fetch only gets
pull for large files, fetch for small ones

questiontext.text: What is rebase in Git?

answer.text: Rewriting commit history to create a more linear history

questiontext.text: What is git stash used for?

answer.text: Creating a permanent backup of a source code

questiontext.text: What is the foundation of Git architecture?
Which command creates a new branch and immediately switches to it?
What is a Pull Request (Merge Request)?

answer.text: Request to merge changes from one branch to another with code review capability
Command to get changes from remote repository

questiontext.text: For which types of files is Git LFS recommended?
What does the git gc command do?

answer.text: Optimizes repository by removing unnecessary objects

questiontext.text: What does the git diff command show?

answer.text: Differences between working directory and last commit
List of all files in repository

questiontext.text: What is the git remote add origin <url> command used for?

answer.text: Adds a remote repository named origin

questiontext.text: Which command adds a file to Git tracking?
What does the abbreviation CI mean in the context of software development?
What is the main goal of Continuous Integration (CI)?

answer.text: Integration of code changes into a shared codebase with automated checks
Test automation only at the release stage
Creating code backups for recovery in case of failures

questiontext.text: What is the difference between Continuous Delivery and Continuous Deployment?

answer.text: Continuous Delivery prepares code for release but requires manual deployment; Continuous Deployment automatically deploys to production
Continuous Delivery includes automatic deployment to production, Continuous Deployment does not
Continuous Deployment only works with containers

questiontext.text: Which stage usually does NOT belong to a standard CI/CD pipeline?
What is NOT an artifact in the CI/CD context?
Which file is used to define a pipeline in GitHub Actions?
What programming language is used to write Jenkinsfile?
Which file is used to define a pipeline in GitLab CI?
What does "Infrastructure as Code" (IaC) mean in the DevOps context?

answer.text: Provisioning and managing infrastructure through code instead of manual processes
Creating infrastructure only in the cloud

questiontext.text: What is the main advantage of Continuous Integration?

answer.text: Fast detection and fixing of errors
Reducing the number of developers in the team

questiontext.text: What are "quality gates" in a CI/CD pipeline?

answer.text: Automated quality thresholds that stop the pipeline when criteria are violated

questiontext.text: What are the three main components described in GitHub Actions workflow?
What is a nightly build?

answer.text: Scheduled build, usually daily, to reduce CI server load
Build that runs only at night
Build only for final product version
Build that runs only during critical errors

questiontext.text: The process of automatic integration of code changes into a shared codebase several times a day followed by automated tests is called:
What does the "Code Quality Analysis" stage include in a CI/CD pipeline?

answer.text: Static analysis to check compliance with quality and security standards

answer.text: Defining CI/CD pipelines through configuration files in the repository
Writing pipelines in C programming language
